results.title: Greetings from Wollongong
results.brief_description: Four unemployed young people roam around one of Australia’s largest industrial cities. Combines social realist fiction with an essay-like examination of the city of Wollongong. This film is equally engaging and intellectually rigorous. As an exploration of a once leading steel-producing city, now increasingly blighted by unemployment, it also becomes a requiem for post-war working class Australia.

results.title: Psycho samba
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description: ‘Suddenly a bolt of electricity sprang forth from the screen and hit me in the head, scorching my forehead with uncanny resemblance of a burn that looked like a human eye. I could hear a buzzing in my ears, my newly formed third eye then began to secrete a special metallic-tasting liquid, as I saw visions of atomic bomb mushroom clouds.’ - Ian Haig (Chicago Underground Film Fest)

results.title: Blood
results.brief_description:
Travelling through Australia with his film camera, Ivan Sen has visited many Aboriginal communities, from urban to prison to distant-rural. Photographing people in their definitive environments, he has created an installation which is a subtle and deeply moving meditation on skin, landscape, gesture and the many nuances of Aboriginal identities.

The work contains imagery of people who have all shared the same blood. The blood of the Gamilaroi people of Northern NSW.

results.title: Instrument
results.brief_description:
Jem Cohen is a New York-based producer working in 16mm and 8mm film and video. His poetic, often ephemeral, work is marked by a blurring of the distinctions between documentary, narrative, and experimental genres. Cohen frequently shoots in hundreds of locations without any additional crew, in the tradition of documentary street photographers such as Robert Frank. His projects include collaborations with poets, writers, and bands such as R.E.M. and Fugazi, creating alternatives to generic and commodified ‘music video.’
‘Instrument’ is a collaboration between Jem Cohen and the Washington DC band Fugazi, the project covers the ten year period from the bands inception in 1987. Far from a traditional documentary, the project is a musical document: a portrait of musicians at work.

results.title: Contests USA
results.brief_description: Skip Blumberg presents, in his customary fashion, a series of short films examining the bizarre and the sublime in America in the 1980s. ‘Summer Ski Jumping’ follows the 33rd annual event ski enthusiasts who take over the Olympic ski jump in Lake Placid on the 4th of July and execute jumps over imported snow sometimes during temperatures reaching 100 degrees. ‘Ugly Dog Contest’ presents a subversion of the traditional dog show with a series of unusual looking dogs in line to take the prize of ugliest dog. ‘Festival of the Saw’ captures the international celebration of saw playing in Santa Cruz, with an examination of the demise of saw playing during the 1920s and its subsequent revival.

results.title: This is a history of New York
results.brief_description: ‘This is a History of New York’ chronicles the seven ages of mankind from Prehistory to the Space Age. In the Age of Hunters and Gatherers, stray dogs patrol the streets while the homeless forage for food. Later in the Medieval Period, crazed street preachers pace frantically before ominous gothic architecture. The richness of Cohen’s vision is found in this haunting imagery and the perception that the thriving city of New York is really the accumulation of humanity’s failures, as well as triumphs.

results.title: Mapping a city of fragments v.2
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: Using the opening of Godard’s film ‘Alphaville’ as a foundation, Lord constructs a vision of the evolving global city during the last years of the 20th Century. Structured as a series of repetitions, the montage of the changing city is offset by shots of Silicon Valley corporate facades. The result is a dialectical contrast between urban and suburban space, body and mind, chaos and order, and the post-modern and the modern. Shot in Hi-8 video in Tokyo, Fukuoka City, Mexico City, Rome, San Francisco, Naples and Los Angeles.

results.title: Wool Fashion Awards of 1960
results.brief_description: Every year, a fashion contest to promote wool as a fabric is held by the Australian Wool Bureau. In 1960, Melbourne compered the awards and this film shows many of the winning entries in the fifty-five sections. Those modelled include suits, coats, dresses, knitwear and slacks. The supreme award for 1960 is the climax of the parade of gold medal winners, held at the end of four days judging.

results.title: Trees to tame the wind
results.brief_description: In this film we are introduced to a farmer and his son who, in 1934, were distressed by the damage wrought by drought and wind to their farm. At the suggestion of the Forest Service Officer, the farmer decided to carry out a Forest Service plan for planting trees to act as wind-breaks and shelter-belts on his farm, as part of the Prairie States Forestry Project “The Shelterbelt” which extended from North Dakota to Texas. By 1939, this kind of tree planting was being encouraged all over the prairie farmlands in the United States with participation by the farmers an essential part of the program.
